title: How do sentences and fragments differ? - Quora

response.answer_text: Pretty simple concept, really. (See, that was a fragment). Believe me. (That was a complete sentence) Most of all, a sentence needs a verb. As long as you have one of those, it’s pretty hard to screw it up. Of course, a subject would also be nice, although the above example proves you don’t always need an explicit one. The subject of that sentence is “you (understood)”. Hang tight. You’re on your way to wrangling sentences like a pro.

A sentence contains a subject, verb, and a complete thought. It makes sense to hear. Examples of sentences: The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog. We went to the store. The dog sleeps. A fragment is a phrase or clause. It is considered incomplete compared to sentences because they do not make sense. Examples of fragments: The dog is Because I said so After we walked down the street
